title: 108_hr3891
content: Use of redevelopment bonds for environmental remediation. Environmental remediation costs for qualified contaminated sites can now be included as a redevelopment purpose under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The costs must be incurred according to an approved environmental remediation plan by the EPA or a designated state/local agency head. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 now allows for environmental remediation costs to be included as a redevelopment purpose. Certain requirements do not apply to bonds issued for financing these costs. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for environmental remediation costs to be included in redevelopment purposes. Bonds issued for financing these costs are subject to specific requirements, including the payment of principal and interest secured by taxes or approval by the elected representative of the governmental unit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for environmental remediation costs to be included in redevelopment purposes. Bonds issued for financing these costs are subject to specific requirements, including the payment of principal and interest secured by taxes or approval by the elected representative of the governmental unit. The term 'environmental remediation' refers to abatement or control of hazardous substances as defined by section 101 of the Comprehensive Environmental Response. The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (42 U.S.C. 9601) covers costs like demolition of contaminated structures, permit fees for remediation, health assessments, and off-site contamination remediation. A qualified contaminated site is defined by specific conditions. The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 covers costs related to contaminated sites. A qualified contaminated site must meet specific conditions for funding under this section, including being unused for at least 1 year, having potential for industrial or commercial redevelopment creating jobs and expanding the tax base, and completing environmental remediation within a reasonable time frame. Failure to satisfactorily complete remediation may result in penalties. Penalty for Failure to Satisfactorily Complete Remediation Plan: No deduction allowed for interest on financing for costs related to contaminated sites if remediation plan is deemed unsatisfactorily completed by the Environmental Protection Agency or designated state/local agency head. The amendments made by this section apply to bonds issued after the enactment of this Act.
